verses.text: Again, Jesus entered the synagogue, and a man was there with a withered hand.
verses.comment: This continues the Sabbath controversy theme. Synagogue healings emphasize Jesus acting with divine authority.

verses.text: And they watched Jesus closely, to see if He would heal him on the Sabbath, so they could accuse Him.
verses.comment: Religious leaders challenge the divine lawgiver. Jesus is foreshadowed as the fulfillment and interpreter of the Law.

verses.text: He said to the man with the withered hand, "Stand up in the middle."
verses.comment: Jesus publicly calls the man forth, inviting all to witness the sign. This shows Christ’s authority in the assembly.

verses.text: Then He said to them, "Is it lawful on the Sabbath to do good, or to do evil? To save life, or to kill?" But they remained silent.
verses.comment: Jesus reframes the Sabbath law, placing compassion above legalism—echoes ancient prophecy about true worship.

verses.text: And looking around at them with anger, grieved by their hardness of heart, He said to the man, "Stretch out your hand." He stretched it out, and his hand was restored.
verses.comment: Hardness of heart echoes Israel's stubbornness in the wilderness. Jesus’ healing signifies restoration to wholeness—both physical and spiritual.

verses.text: And the Pharisees went out and immediately began plotting with the Herodians against Him, on how to destroy Him.
verses.comment: Opposition to Jesus joins religious and political forces, as foretold in Psalm 2 about Messiah facing plots by rulers.

verses.text: Jesus withdrew with His disciples to the sea, and a large crowd from Galilee followed Him.
verses.comment: Jesus' retreat and gathering of the people symbolizes drawing all nations to Himself—a prefiguring of missionary expansion.

verses.text: And from Judea, Jerusalem, Idumea, beyond the Jordan, and around Tyre and Sidon, a vast crowd came to Him, hearing all that He was doing.
verses.comment: Regions listed show the gathering of Jews and Gentiles alike; prophecy foretold the Messiah would draw all people.

verses.text: And He instructed His disciples to have a small boat ready for Him, because of the crowd, lest they crush Him.
verses.comment: The need for order amid the crowds prefigures future organization among believers gathering around Christ.

verses.text: For He had healed many, so that all who were sick pressed in to touch Him.
verses.comment: Jesus as healer fulfills prophecy about the Suffering Servant carrying our infirmities (Isa 53:4).

verses.text: Whenever unclean spirits saw Him, they fell down before Him and cried out, "You are the Son of God!"
verses.comment: Demons openly confess Jesus' divine sonship, confirming His messianic authority foretold in scripture.

verses.text: But He strictly ordered them not to make Him known.
verses.comment: The 'Messianic secret'—Jesus chose the time and means of revealing His divine mission, avoiding premature misunderstandings.

verses.text: He went up the mountain and called to Him those He Himself wanted, and they came to Him.
verses.comment: Jesus' ascent of the mountain recalls Moses' communion with God, indicating His divine authority to appoint leaders.

verses.text: He appointed twelve, whom He named apostles, so they might be with Him and that He might send them out to preach
verses.comment: The twelve represent the restored tribes of Israel, showing the Church’s apostolic foundation and mission.

verses.text: and to have authority to cast out demons.
verses.comment: Jesus shares His divine authority with the apostles; their unique spiritual power is attested throughout the New Testament.

verses.text: He appointed Simon (to whom He gave the name Peter);
verses.comment: Naming Peter ('Rock') designates a unique role of leadership among the apostles, prefiguring spiritual stewardship.

verses.text: James the son of Zebedee, and John the brother of James (He gave them the name Boanerges, which means 'sons of thunder');
verses.comment: Special nicknames show intimate relationship with Jesus and spiritual distinctiveness among the apostles.

verses.text: and Andrew, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, James the son of Alphaeus, Thaddeus, and Simon the Zealot;
verses.comment: The listing of the apostles affirms the importance of personal calling and historical continuity within the faith.

verses.text: and Judas Iscariot, who betrayed Him.
verses.comment: Judas’ betrayal fulfills Psalm 41:9 and emphasizes both the humanity and sacrificial destiny of Christ’s chosen community.

verses.text: Then Jesus went home; and again a crowd gathered, so that He and His disciples could not even eat.
verses.comment: Crowds persistently seek Jesus, underscoring His compassion and the growing centrality of His ministry.

verses.text: When His family heard about this, they went out to restrain Him, saying, "He is out of His mind."
verses.comment: Jesus’ family misunderstanding foreshadows the tension between earthly relationships and devotion to the Kingdom.

verses.text: And the scribes who came down from Jerusalem said, "He is possessed by Beelzebul," and, "By the prince of demons He casts out demons."
verses.comment: This charge of alliance with evil spirits is a provocative denial of Jesus' divine power, increasing His conflict with the religious elite.

verses.text: And He called them to Himself and spoke to them in parables, "How can Satan cast out Satan?"
verses.comment: Jesus uses logic and parable to refute the accusation, showing He possesses divine wisdom in confronting error.

verses.text: "If a kingdom is divided against itself, that kingdom cannot stand."
verses.comment: The unity and stability of Christ's true kingdom are implicitly contrasted with division and collapse.

verses.text: "And if a house is divided against itself, that house will not be able to stand."
verses.comment: Unity is prized in Christ's teaching as a sign of divine presence and spiritual health.

verses.text: "And if Satan has risen up against himself and is divided, he cannot stand, but is about to come to an end."
verses.comment: Jesus alluding to the ultimate destruction of evil at the end of days, promising victory for His kingdom.

verses.text: "But no one can enter a strong man's house and plunder his goods unless he first binds the strong man. Then indeed he may plunder his house."
verses.comment: Jesus portrays His ministry as binding the enemy, freeing souls; Isaiah foretold the deliverance of captives from evil.

verses.text: "Truly I say to you, all sins will be forgiven the children of men, and whatever blasphemies they utter,"
verses.comment: Jesus reveals the generous scope of divine mercy, a theme central in both Old and New Testament covenants.

verses.text: "but whoever blasphemes against the Holy Spirit never has forgiveness, but is guilty of an eternal sin."
verses.comment: Jesus warns against final impenitence resisting God's grace. The necessity of cooperating with grace is emphasized.

verses.text: For they said, "He has an unclean spirit."
verses.comment: Attributing God's work to evil is the root of the unforgivable sin, highlighting discernment’s vital role for believers.

verses.text: And His mother and His brothers came, and standing outside, they sent word to Him and called Him.
verses.comment: Jesus’ family standing outside contrasts with the spiritual intimacy He offers disciples gathered near.

verses.text: And a crowd was sitting around Him, and they said to Him, "Your mother and your brothers are outside looking for You."
verses.comment: Physical family seeks Jesus; spiritual family sits at His feet, underscoring new relationships in faith and obedience.

verses.text: And He answered them, "Who are My mother and My brothers?"
verses.comment: Jesus prompts a reflection on true kinship not by flesh, but by spiritual communion.

verses.text: Looking around at those sitting with Him, He said, "Here are My mother and My brothers!"
verses.comment: Jesus defines His family as those united to Him in love and obedience; this models the spiritual household surrounding Christ.

verses.text: "For whoever does the will of God, he is My brother and sister and mother."
verses.comment: Participation in God’s will draws believers into intimate spiritual kinship with Christ, signifying a united, holy community.
